message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The EKG findings and the symptoms after medication administration suggest that the patient has atrial fibrillation and the medication administered was an anti-arrhythmic. Among the options, only (A) decreased rate of phase 0 depolarization and increased action potential duration is consistent with the mechanism of action of Class I anti-arrhythmic drugs. The other options are not commonly associated with this class of drugs.

We refer to Wikipedia and other medical sources for help. The EKG findings and the symptoms after medication administration suggest the use of a class I antiarrhythmic drug, which works by decreasing the rate of phase 0 depolarization and increasing action potential duration, leading to a decrease in conduction velocity and refractoriness. Option A is the only one that matches this description.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of ringing in the ears, headache, flushed skin, and a spinning sensation suggest a side effect of the medication. Fast sawtooth waves on the EKG suggest atrial flutter or fibrillation, and the medication administered most likely has properties of decreasing the rate of phase 0 depolarization and increasing action potential duration, such as a class IC antiarrhythmic agent.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms (ringing in ears, headache, flushed skin, and a spinning sensation) suggest a side effect of a medication that affects the cardiovascular system. Among the options, decreased rate of phase 0 depolarization and increased action potential duration are properties of Class I antiarrhythmic drugs, such as procainamide or quinidine, which may cause side effects like tinnitus, headache, and dizziness. The fast sawtooth waves on EKG suggest atrial flutter.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the medication administered was an antiarrhythmic drug, likely Class Ia, which has a decreased rate of phase 0 depolarization and increased action potential duration. This can lead to adverse effects like tinnitus, headache, and nausea. Option B has a decreased action potential duration, which is not consistent with the symptoms. Option C has an increased action potential duration, which is consistent with the symptoms, but the rate of phase 0 depolarization is normal, which is not typical of Class Ia antiarrhythmic drugs. Option D has normal rate of phase 0 depolarization and action potential duration, which is also not typical of Class Ia antiarrhythmic drugs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fast sawtooth waves on EKG suggest atrial flutter with a rate of 200/min. The medication given was likely an antiarrhythmic, and the symptoms suggest an adverse reaction to class IA antiarrhythmics, which decrease the rate of phase 0 depolarization and increase action potential duration. Option A is the only one that fits this description.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the medication that was most likely administered is an antiarrhythmic drug, and among the options, only option A describes the properties of a class I antiarrhythmic drug, which decreases rate of phase 0 depolarization and increases action potential duration. The symptoms of ringing in the ears, headache, flushed skin, and a spinning sensation are common side effects of class I antiarrhythmic drugs.

The fast sawtooth waves at 200/min suggest atrial fibrillation, and the symptoms after medication administration suggest a side effect of class I antiarrhythmics. Among the options, only (A) has the properties of decreasing rate of phase 0 depolarization and increasing action potential duration, which is characteristic of class I antiarrhythmics.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest that he received an antiarrhythmic drug that caused adverse effects. Among the options, only option A fits the description of Class IA antiarrhythmic drugs, which decrease the rate of phase 0 depolarization and increase action potential duration.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of ringing in the ears, headache, flushed skin, and a spinning sensation are suggestive of a adverse reaction to a medication that affects the cardiovascular system. The fast sawtooth waves on the EKG suggest atrial flutter or fibrillation, and the medication most likely administered would be one that decreases the rate of phase 0 depolarization and increases action potential duration. This would suggest a medication that affects the AV node or the His-Purkinje system, such as a beta-blocker or calcium channel blocker.
